keyTakeAways: At least 64 people have died in Mexico due to heavy rains and flooding affecting five states.
Another 65 people are still missing, with the highest numbers in Veracruz (29 deaths), Hidalgo (21 deaths), Puebla (13 deaths), and Queretaro (1 death).
Forty-three people are missing in Hidalgo, 18 in Veracruz, and four in Puebla.
The flooding was caused by the remnants of Hurricane Priscilla and Tropical Rainstorm Raymond, leading to rapid river rises, landslides, and widespread destruction.
The heaviest rainfall was recorded in Cerro Azul (Veracruz) and Cuetzalan del Progreso (Puebla), with 280mm and 286mm of rain respectively.
Thousands of military troops have been deployed, including the Mexican Army, Air Force, and National Guard, to deliver food, water, and aid to isolated areas.
Nearly 400 repair workers have restored over 80% of electricity supply across five states, where around 263,000 users lost power.
The National Civil Protection Coordination (CNPC) chief, Laura Velazquez Alzua, highlighted the lack of early meteorological warnings to predict the severity of rainfall.
President Claudia Sheinbaum addressed the crisis, noting that there were no signs in the alert system indicating such extreme rainfall.
Over 100,000 houses have been affected, with some structures near rivers reportedly 'practically disappeared'.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Mexico has suffered severe flooding due to heavy rains from the remnants of Hurricane Priscilla and Tropical Rainstorm Raymond, resulting in at least 64 deaths and 65 people still missing across five states. The hardest-hit areas are Veracruz (29 deaths), Hidalgo (21 deaths), and Puebla (13 deaths). The heaviest rainfall occurred in Cerro Azul and Cuetzalan del Progreso. Over 100,000 homes were affected, with some structures destroyed. The Mexican military and emergency services have responded with aid deliveries and power restoration, with 80% of electricity restored.
